text: the mystique of the Mekong the kun
waterfalls in southern Laos are among
the most beautiful little-known section
of the nearly five thousand kilometer
long Mekong River or maenam Kong as it's
known here in southern Laos
this is Thomas fuller
reporting from Danza Hong Laos
French explorers in the 19th century
hope that the Mekong could become
Southeast Asia's Mississippi a great
watery highway connecting southern China
with the sea
treacherous Rapids and the waterfalls -
those hopes but the natural obstacles
also seem to ensure that the river would
remain wild and pristine today the
character of what is the world's twelfth
longest river is set for rapid change
driven by growing demands for
electricity galloping economic growth
and the slow fade into history of the
ideological conflict that gripped this
part of the world in recent decades who
knew of Gale jumpa a village head man is
a supporter of a dam project here in
danza hall there won't be any
development here if we do not build this
Dam
if we cannot catch fish here we will go
to another place fish will find another
way to travel upstream if the dam is
built it will improve the economy here
not everyone is happy with the prospect
of a more modern McConville fishermen
who have long relied on the great bounty
of the river are alarmed at plans for
numerous dams that experts say will
damage fish populations and with it the
multi-billion dollar fishing industry
the dongseong dam in particular will
block a channel crucial for migratory
fish and it's one of 70 dams plan for
the Mekong and its tributaries in Laos
alone
further north China is halfway through
construction of its fourth dam on the
river but it's the downstream dams like
the one planned here that experts
believe will be the most disruptive for
migratory fish
the fish will have no place to go
the fish can only go up to the Siham
channel and the Sadam channel the rest
are all too steep there will definitely
be less fish because the dam will be in
their way whether the dams go ahead or
not scenes like these are increasingly
common the Mekong in many parts of its
winding course is no longer a wild and
primitive backwater
